title: ASIC wins appeal in Westpac super rollover row
text:
The Australian Securities and Investments Commission has been successful in appealing its loss against Westpac in the “test case” over the crucial definition of general financial advice.

A three-judge panel of the The Federal Court ruled on Monday that ASIC’s appeal of a previous court decision from December 2018 be allowed with costs, dismissing a counter-appeal by Westpac subsidiary BT Funds Management.

Justice Jacqueline Gleeson ruled in December 2018 that Westpac was in breach of corporations law and its ethical obligation to members in its actions to roll over more than $640 million in superannuation balances to Westpac-owned, BT-branded super funds.

However, while the court found the bank’s subsidiaries had not provided financial services “efficiently, honestly and fairly”, crucially it did not rule that the recommendation to transfer the balances to BT funds amounted to “personal advice” instead of “general advice”.

ASIC alleged that the telephone-based campaigns of Westpac’s so-called Super Activation Team, commenced in 2014, crossed the line from general financial product advice to personal financial product advice, which the relevant bank subsidiaries, Westpac Securities and BT Funds Management, were not licensed to provide.

ASIC had been hoping to use the dispute as a “test case”, providing much-needed clarity on the legal line between personal and general advice. It announced it would appeal the decision in February 2019.
